2.text: We’re here at the Eden Project in Cornwall

4.text:
to meet some fabulous flora
for the first ever BiPPAs,

10.text:
These awards showcase 
the glitzy glamour goddesses,

16.text: and vile villains of the plant kingdom.

18.text: Let's roll out the red carpet!

22.text: First up is our award for the Best Communicator.

25.text:
Plants have some surprising ways 
of communicating with each other,

28.text:
from pollinators and even 
with their own structures.

32.text:
If you want to reach the giddy heights, 
take control of your hormones,

37.text:
Or perhaps like the Traveller’s palm, 
pollinated by lemurs in Madagascar,

41.text:
you’ll choose to orientate yourself 
with the compass.

44.text:
But can a plant communicate 
danger or protect itself?

48.text:
Broad beans are known to activate anti-aphid defences 
when a nearby plant is being attacked,

53.text: and a touch on the Sensitive plant

55.text:
triggers a lightning-quick electrochemical 
response, closing its leaves.

60.text:
Plants need to attract pollinators, and colour, 
shape and pattern all play their part.

66.text:
Our winner then of the 
award for Best Communicator

68.text:
goes to extraordinary lengths 
to communicate to its pollinators.

73.text:
And our winner is the Titan arum 
from Western Sumatra.

77.text:
It produces an overpowering stench of 
rotting flesh that attracts pollinators,

81.text: such as flesh flies and beetles.

84.text:
The stench is so bad that 
it's often called the corpse flower.

87.text:
It even heats up to body temperature, which 
means that its flowering is very short-lived.

94.text:
From the beautiful to the bizarre, 
our next award is for the Best Costume.

99.text:
The clock vine is pollinated by sunbirds and 
hummingbirds and is definitely eye-catching.

105.text:
At the other end of the spectrum, the mature 
Baobab tree looks like it's upside-down.

109.text:
This hardy species can regrow 
its bark if stripped bare

113.text:
and is even able to resist 
drought, fire and termites.

117.text:
Following fashion trends might be 
highly-prized for some people,

121.text:
but there are plants that use 
mimicry to their advantage,

124.text:
either to attract or restrict 
particular pollinators.

128.text:
The shape of the beautiful flowers of Heliconia, 
sometimes called Lobster-claws,

132.text:
limit pollination to a subset of 
the hummingbird population.

136.text:
The Jade vine has almost luminous green 
flowers to attract bats at twilight.

141.text:
While the bat drinks nectar from the flowers, 
the top of its head brushes against the pollen.

146.text:
This is then left on the female part 
of the next flower the bat visits.

152.text:
However, our winner of the 
Best Costume award goes to... the tulip.

157.text:
Tulips come in a variety 
of colours and forms.

160.text:
In the 17th Century the tulip stirred such a 
passion and frenzy when it arrived into Europe,

167.text:
Dutch merchantmen coveted the bulbs 
that became a luxury item,

173.text:
These are caused by specific 
viruses in the plant.

179.text: Our next award is for Best Adaption.

182.text:
Whether genetic adaptation 
from human influence

184.text:
or the ability to survive in 
hostile or unusual habitats.

189.text: When we think about survival in extremes,

191.text:
succulent plants such as 
Cacti quickly come to mind.

195.text:
Their modified leaves limit desiccation and 
their spines provide protection from animals.

201.text:
Bromeliads are epiphytes that 
adapt to a host of environments,

205.text: obtaining nutrients from air and rainfall,

207.text:
with their scales and hairs 
helping to trap moisture.

211.text:
Gorse is amazing at adapting 
to its environment.

213.text:
Its sharp spikes protect it 
from hungry animals;

216.text:
its flowers attract pollinators with their 
bright yellow petals and fragrance

220.text:
and its seeds are ejected 
when they are ripe.

222.text:
Gorse is also a fire-climax plant 
that re-grows from the roots after fire.

228.text:
Lichens are not just one organism but also 
a partnership between an alga and fungus.

234.text:
They colonise some of the most 
inhospitable habitats on earth,

238.text:
surviving on high mountains and 
hostile regions such as the Arctic,

241.text:
and can be vitally important 
sources of food for animals.

246.text:
However, our award for Best Adaptation 
goes to the none other than rice.

251.text:
Originating in China, rice is the 
world’s number one food crop,

258.text:
You could almost say we humans 
are adapted to exploiting it

261.text:
and even consider it a 
symbol of life and fertility.

265.text: But what makes rice really stand out

266.text:
is the opportunity to address 
health and malnutrition.

270.text:
Using genetic modification, a golden rice grain 
has now been produced to carry vitamin A,

276.text:
helping to provide a controversial 
solution to global famine.

281.text: Next, our award for Best Villain.

284.text: Some are deadly in their own right;

286.text:
others are only villains because 
we humans just can’t say no.

290.text:
Just like certain humans, some 
plants need to supplement their diet.

295.text:
Carnivorous plants have developed 
ingenious ways to lure and trap insects

299.text:
to provide them with 
essential nutrients.

302.text:
The Yellow pitcher lures insects inside the 
flower with sugar that is laced with alkaloids,

308.text:
intoxicating their prey and 
making escape impossible.

312.text: They may be toxic but they still have their uses.

315.text:
Californian Buckeye was used by 
Native Americans to help catch fish.

320.text:
By crushing the toxic seeds 
and throwing them into a river,

324.text:
hungry fish would die 
and provide easy pickings.

328.text:
Then there's just a whole host of 
plants we just can't do without.

332.text: These Oil palms might not be villains,

334.text:
but our appetite for palm oil has led to 
rainforest destruction and a rise in obesity.

339.text:
However, the award for Best Villain 
goes to a plant we just cannot say no to.

344.text:
But it's an award that 
is certainly unfair.

347.text:
It's not the plant that's the villain; 
it's us and how we crave it.

351.text:
Sugar cane was perhaps 
the first mass-produced crop.

355.text: It's also associated with slave labour.

358.text:
We are often unaware of how 
much sugar we are consuming

360.text:
and diabetes is now one of the 
fastest growing health risks of our time.

366.text:
Our final prize is for the 
Lifetime Achievement award.

371.text:
A plant that is so useful 
we cannot imagine life with it,

380.text:
be a plant that we are prepared to go 
to extraordinary lengths to harvest,

384.text:
such as the Vanilla orchid 
that requires hand pollination?

388.text:
Maybe we should consider plants that have been 
around since the dinosaurs walked the earth,

392.text:
such as Horsetail Restio and 
flowering plants, such as Protea.

397.text:
All worthy contenders, but for us we’ve 
found a plant that is extremely long-lived,

401.text:
with some specimens 
over 3,000 years old.

405.text:
Our winner of the Lifetime Achievement 
award goes to the humble Yew.

410.text:
It can tolerate a wide range of 
conditions, temperature and humidity.

415.text:
The yew has been the 
focus of myth and legend,

417.text:
and its wood was once used 
to make the English longbow.

420.text:
And despite being largely toxic, 
it even has medicinal uses.

425.text:
Taxol has been isolated from the yew 
and is now used as a chemotherapy drug,

430.text:
serving to remind us that beyond 
what we see on the surface,

433.text:
this plant – and all of 
our worthy winners –

435.text:
provide us with so much more 
than just being green.
